courseTitle: Greenhouse Gases and Sea Level Rise

pageData.titleName2: Greenhouse Gases and Sea Level Rise

pageData.text: In this laboratory, students will carry out several activities aimed at demonstrating two consequences of <button class='glossary-text'>anthropogenic</button> carbon emissions and <button class='glossary-text'>climate</button> change: <button class='glossary-text'>sea level rise</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>ocean acidification</button>. Sea level rise, in particular, is a subject that garners much attention in the contemporary study of geology, especially in the areas of coastal and marine geology. To complete this lab, students will first create a landform <button class='glossary-text'>model</button> based on a contour map. They will create models of sea level rise resulting from melting of sea ice and glacier ice and examine the effects of this potential consequence of climate change. The students will then model ocean acidification resulting from increased carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) in the atmosphere. Students will critically examine the model systems used in the experiments.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 24 hours 
 Activity 1: Building a Model from a Contour Map - 2 hours 
 Activity 2: Sea Ice and Sea Level Rise - 1 hour 
 Activity 3: Glacier Ice and Sea Level Rise - 2.5 hours 
 Activity 4: Ocean Acidification - 30 minutes 
 Activity 5: Improving the Model (Optional) - 45 minutes
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 24 hours 
 Activity 1: Building a Model from a Contour Map - 2 hours 
 Activity 2: Sea Ice and Sea Level Rise - 1 hour 
 Activity 3: Glacier Ice and Sea Level Rise - 2.5 hours 
 Activity 4: Ocean Acidification - 30 minutes 
 Activity 5: Improving the Model (Optional) - 45 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Overview video: Greenhouse Gases and Sea Level Rise

text: Explain the causes of increased carbon emissions and their likely effect on global <button class='glossary-text'>climate</button>.
Discuss positive and negative climate <button class='glossary-text'>feedback</button>.
Distinguish between glacial ice melt and oceanic ice melt.
Measure the effect of CO<sub>2</sub> gas on seawater acidity.
Construct a 3-D <button class='glossary-text'>model</button> from a 2-D contour map.
Evaluate and improve a model system.

pageData.text: Coral reefs are incredibly important biodiversity hotspots in marine environments that rely on coral as both their primary producer and a structural matrix providing shelter and protection. Unfortunately, coral is also one of the organisms that is most susceptible to the negative consequences of increased <button class='glossary-text'>greenhouse gases</button>. As global CO<sub>2</sub> levels rise, the oceans become not only more acidic, but also warmer. Increased acidity dissolves the calcium carbonate matrix that corals secrete, which makes up most of the structure of the reef, thus making it harder for the coral to lay down new skeletons as they grow.  Corals are animals that contain mutualistic, photosynthetic zooxanthellae within them, providing much of the energy to the coral and the rest of the ecosystem. However, these zooxanthellae are very sensitive to temperature changes. Even a small increase in ocean temperatures can cause them to die off, leaving the coral nutrient deficient. The coral subsequently dies. What remains is the white calcium carbonate skeleton, a phenomenon called coral reef bleaching.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>Coral reefs also directly benefit humans. They help dissipate the energy of hurricanes and protect coastlines from potentially deadly storm surges. However, increased ocean temperatures have led to increased storm intensity and frequency, damaging coral reefs that cannot recover fast enough.

pageData.desc: Bleached coral in the background. Several small marine fish in the foreground.
pageData.altText: Bleached coral in the background. Several small marine fish in the foreground.

pageData.text: For the last 30 years, controversy has surrounded the ideas of global warming/<button class='glossary-text'>climate</button> change. However, the scientific concepts behind the theory are not new. In the 1820s, Joseph Fourier was the first to recognize that, given the earth’s size and distance from the sun, the planet’s surface temperature should be considerably cooler than it was. He proposed several mechanisms to explain why the earth was warmer than his calculations predicted, one of which was that the earth’s atmosphere might act as an insulator. Forty years later, John Tyndall demonstrated that different gases have different capacities to absorb infrared radiation, most notably methane (CH<sub>4</sub>), carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>), and water vapor (H<sub>2</sub>O), all of which are present in the atmosphere. In 1896, Svante Arrhenius developed the first mathematical <button class='glossary-text'>model</button>  of the effect of increased CO<sub>2</sub> levels on temperature. His model predicted that a doubling of the amount of CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere would produce a 5 to 6° C increase in temperature globally. Based on the level of CO<sub>2</sub> production in the late 19th century, he predicted that this change would take place over thousands of years, if at all. Arrhenius used Arvid Högbom’s calculations of industrial CO<sub>2</sub> emissions in his equations. Högbom thought that the excess CO<sub>2</sub> would be absorbed by the ocean; others believed that the effect of CO<sub>2</sub> was insignificant next to the much larger effect of water vapor.

It was not until the late 1950s, when the CO<sub>2</sub> absorption capacity of the ocean was better understood and significant increases in CO<sub>2</sub> levels were being observed by G. S. Callendar (a 10% increase from the 1850s to the 1950s), that Arrhenius’s calculations received renewed attention.

pageData.subTitle: The Atmosphere
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Weather</button> is the condition of the atmosphere in a given location at a specific time. Climate is the prevailing weather pattern over a longer period (decades or centuries).

The atmosphere is a thin shell (~100 km) of gases that envelops the earth. It is made up principally of nitrogen (78%), oxygen (21%), and argon (0.9%). Trace gases include methane, ozone (O<sub>3</sub>), CO<sub>2</sub>, carbon monoxide (CO), and oxides of nitrogen (e.g., NO<sub>2</sub>) and sulfur (e.g., SO<sub>2</sub>). Water vapor is not usually included in the composition of gases in the atmosphere because it varies widely, from 0% to 4%, depending on location. The concentration of gases in the atmosphere is not uniform either; the atmosphere consists of several concentric layers. Some gases are concentrated at certain altitudes. Water is concentrated near Earth’s surface, for instance, and ozone is concentrated 20 to 30 kilometers above the surface. Transfer of energy from the sun at and near the surface of the earth is responsible for weather and climate. Solar radiation heats land, the oceans, and atmospheric gases differently, resulting in the constant transfer of energy across the globe.

Several factors interact to cause areas of Earth’s surface and atmosphere to heat at different rates, called <button class='glossary-text'>differential heating</button>. The first is the angle at which the sun’s light hits the earth. Where the sun is directly overhead, as it is at the equator, the light is direct. Each square mile of incoming sunlight hits one square mile of the earth. At higher latitudes, the sun hits at an angle, spreading the one square mile of sunlight over more of Earth’s surface. Thus, the intensity of the light is reduced and the surface does not warm as quickly (see Figure 1). This causes the tropics, near the equator, to be warmer and the poles to be cooler.

Different materials absorb heat and cool at different rates. Dark surfaces heat faster than light surfaces. Water has a high <button class='glossary-text'>heat capacity</button>, which is important on a planet whose surface is 72% water. Heat capacity is the number of heat units required to raise the temperature of a substance by 1 degree. The heat capacity of water in liquid form is roughly 4 times that of air. Water is slow to warm and slow to cool, relative to land. This contributes to differential heating of the earth.

Differential heating causes circulation, both in the atmosphere and in the oceans. Warmer fluids are less dense and rise, leaving behind an area of low pressure. Air and water move laterally to equalize the change in pressure. This is critical in developing prevailing wind patterns and in cycling nutrients through the ocean.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Image of the sun’s light shining on Earth at an angle in a higher latitute, spreading the sunlight over more of Earth’s surface than the light shining at the equator.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Image of the sun’s light shining on Earth at an angle in a higher latitute, spreading the sunlight over more of Earth’s surface than the light shining at the equator.

pageData.subTitle: The Role of the Oceans
pageData.text: The oceans play an important role in regulating the atmosphere as well. The large volume of the oceans, combined with the high <button class='glossary-text'>heat capacity</button> of water, prevent volatile temperature swings in the atmosphere. When the percentage of a gas in the atmosphere increases, the rate of diffusion of the gas across the water/air interface increases. The relatively large surface area of the oceans, ~70% of the surface of Earth, means that the oceans can absorb large amounts of atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub>. When seawater absorbs CO<sub>2</sub>, chemical reactions take place that lower seawater pH by forming carbonic acid as well as bicarbonate and carbonate (Figure 2).

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Dissolved carbon dioxide plus water can form carbonic acid, which can form bicarbonate and a hydrogen ion, which can form carbonate and two hydrogen ions. Each reaction can take place in reverse as well as forwards.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Dissolved carbon dioxide plus water can form carbonic acid, which can form bicarbonate and a hydrogen ion, which can form carbonate and two hydrogen ions. Each reaction can take place in reverse as well as forwards.

pageData.text: How long it takes the CO<sub>2</sub> and its derivatives to diffuse throughout the oceans depends largely on ocean currents, which are in turn affected by the atmosphere.

pageData.question: What happens to sunlight when it hits the Earth at higher altitudes?

options.text: The light spreads over more of Earth’s surface.
The light increases Earth’s atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub>.
The light causes volatile temperature swings.
The light causes warmer surface temperatures near the poles.
The light absorbs large amounts of atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub>.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: At higher latitudes, the sun hits at an angle, spreading sunlight over more of Earth’s surface. Thus, the intensity of the light is reduced, and the surface does not warm as quickly.

pageData.question: Why is the equator warmer than the poles?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Where the sun is directly overhead, as it is at the equator, the light is direct, and the earth’s surface warms faster.

Thus, the intensity of the light is reduced, and the surface does not warm as quickly.Different materials absorb heat and cool at different rates. Dark surfaces heat faster than light surfaces. pageData.subTitle: Greenhouse Gases
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>greenhouse effect</button> is a natural process, without which the earth would be significantly cooler. The sun emits energy in a broad range of wavelengths. Most energy from the sun passes through the atmosphere. Some is reflected by the atmosphere and some by Earth’s surface back into space, but much of it is absorbed by the atmosphere and Earth’s surface. Energy absorbed is converted into infrared energy, or heat. Oxygen and nitrogen allow incoming sunlight and outgoing thermal infrared energy to pass through. Water vapor, CO<sub>2</sub>, methane, and some trace gases absorb infrared energy. These are the <button class='glossary-text'>greenhouse gases</button>. After absorbing energy, the greenhouse gases radiate it in all directions, causing the temperature of the atmosphere and the earth to rise.

Greenhouse gases that contribute to the insulation of the earth can be grouped into 2 categories: and . Persistent gases—such as CO2, methane, nitrous oxide (N2O), and ozone (O3)—exist in the environment for much longer periods of time than condensable gases. These times can range from a few years to thousands of years. The longer residence allows them to become well-mixed geographically. The amount of a condensable gas is temperature dependent. Water is the primary greenhouse gas in the atmosphere, but because it is condensable, it is not considered a as it typically cycles into and out of the atmosphere every 9 days. Forcing factors (forcings) are features of the earth’s system that drive climate change; they may be internal or external to the planet and its atmosphere. are events that take place as a result of forcings.

Carbon dioxide, methane, and other gases identified by Tyndall as having high heat capacities make up a relatively minor fraction of the atmosphere, but they have a critical effect on the temperature of the earth. Without the naturally occurring greenhouse effect, it is estimated that the earth’s average temperature would be approximately —18° C (0° F). The greenhouse effect also acts as a buffer, slowing both the warming during the day and the cooling at night. This is an important feature of the earth’s atmosphere. Without the greenhouse effect, the temperature would drop below the freezing point of water and the amount of water in the atmosphere would plummet, creating a . A feedback loop is a mechanism that either enhances () or dampens () the effect that triggers it.

Since the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased from approximately 280 ppm to 379 ppm. This change is attributed to the burning of fossil fuels—such as coal, oil, and natural gas—and changes in land use, i.e., cutting down large tracts of old-growth forests. Old-growth forests, like fossil fuels, sequester carbon from the atmosphere. Burning of either releases that carbon into the atmosphere in the form of CO2. Clearing old-growth forests has an additional impact on the carbon cycle, because trees actively remove CO2 from the atmosphere to convert it to sugar and carbohydrates. Removing long-lived trees and replacing them with short-lived crops and grasses reduces the time over which the carbon is removed from the atmosphere.
Determining the exact effect that the increase in CO<sub>2</sub> concentrations will have on atmospheric temperature is complicated by a variety of interactions and potential feedback loops.

pageData.question: Without naturally occurring greenhouse gases, approximately what would the Earth’s temperature be?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Without the naturally occurring greenhouse effect, it is estimated that the earth’s average temperature would be approximately –18° C (0° F).

pageData.question: What is the primary condensable greenhouse gas in the atmosphere?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Water is the primary greenhouse gas in the atmosphere, but because it is condensable, it is not considered a forcing factor as it typically cycles into and out of the atmosphere every 9 days.

pageData.subTitle: Potential Feedback Loops
pageData.text: Some examples of potential <button class='glossary-text'>positive feedback loops</button> that may increase the effects of global warming are:

1. Higher temperatures cause more ocean water to evaporate as water vapor enters into the atmosphere. More water vapor in the atmosphere traps more heat, further increasing temperature.
  2. Melting of sea ice and glaciers, which are relatively light in color, to darker bodies of water decreases the (the amount of energy reflected back into space) of Earth’s surface, increasing temperatures.
  3. Warmer temperatures melt more of the arctic permafrost, releasing methane into the atmosphere, further raising temperatures.
  4. Higher temperatures may result in greater rainfall in the North Atlantic, and melting of sea ice creates a warm surface layer of fresh water there. This would block formation of sea ice and disrupt the sinking of cold, salty water. It may also slow deep oceanic currents that carry carbon, oxygen, nutrients, and heat around the globe.
Other factors may work as negative <button class='glossary-text'>feedbacks</button>, dampening the effects of global warming:

1. An increase in the CO2 level in the atmosphere leads to an increase in CO2 in the oceans, stabilizing CO2 levels.
  2. Increased atmospheric temperatures and CO2 promote plant and algae growth, increasing absorption of CO2 from the atmosphere, lowering the CO2 levels there and stabilizing temperature.
  3. Warmer air, carrying more moisture, produces more snow at high latitudes. This increases the albedo of Earth’s surface, stabilizing temperature.
  4. Warmer, moister air produces more clouds, which also increases the albedo of Earth’s surface, stabilizing temperature.

The relative impact of each of these potential effects is a subject of debate and leads to the uncertainty in <button class='glossary-text'>models</button> used to predict future <button class='glossary-text'>climate</button> change resulting from an increase in <button class='glossary-text'>anthropogenic</button> (human-caused) <button class='glossary-text'>greenhouse gases</button>.

pageData.subTitle: Possible Consequences
pageData.text: Consequences of an increase in average temperature are difficult to predict on a regional scale; some consequences, however, can be predicted with a relatively high degree of confidence. One of these is <button class='glossary-text'>sea level rise</button>. Sea level rise is the result of two processes. The first is the melting of glaciers and Antarctic continental ice. Whereas the melting of sea ice can have complex consequences due to the different densities of salt and fresh water, it will not cause sea level rise. Melting of glaciers and the deep ice over the Antarctic continent, however, can. The second cause of sea level rise, related to warmer temperatures, is that water slightly expands as it warms. As the oceans warm, the water rises farther up the shore. Countries and cities that have large portions of their land area at or just above sea level may be in jeopardy.

The loss of mountain glaciers is already causing changes in freshwater availability. As glaciers shrink, regions that depend on seasonal meltwater for either hydroelectric power or for irrigation and drinking water are increasingly affected. Whereas rainfall may increase in these regions (even as the amount of snowmelt decreases), rainwater is considerably more difficult to control, because it does not occur at as predictable a rate as meltwater. River systems may be overwhelmed by increased runoff rates, which can cause flooding. One of the richest agricultural regions in the world, California, depends heavily on snowmelt from the Sierra Nevada, and one of the world’s most populous river valleys, the Indus, is equally dependent on snowmelt from the Himalayas.

<button class='glossary-text'>Ocean acidification</button> is another potential consequence of increased atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> levels. Early climate researchers believed that the ocean would eventually absorb much of the anthropogenic CO<sub>2</sub>. How much it will ultimately be able to absorb is still a matter of debate, but CO<sub>2</sub> absorption is not without consequences. As already discussed, absorption of CO<sub>2</sub> by seawater results in lowering of seawater pH and changes in biologically important calcium carbonate minerals.

Most organisms are adapted to a narrow range of pH, and any shift can cause stress to entire ecosystems. For instance, an increase in ocean acidity will have a negative effect on production of shells made of calcium carbonate.

Less predictable consequences are the shifting of global <button class='glossary-text'>weather</button> patterns and the subsequent changes in natural populations. Areas previously ideal for agriculture may become too arid for crop growth. Climes that are more northerly may experience an increase in productivity. These shifts will put stress on ecosystems as well. How resilient each community is to the change will vary with location and other pressures.

pageData.subTitle: Modeling
pageData.text: The atmosphere and are highly complex systems that are challenging to understand and predict. To explore complex systems, scientists frequently employ . A model is a simplification of a complex process that isolates certain factors likely to be important. Sometimes a model can be a physical representation of something too big or too small to see, such as a model solar system. Frequently, scientists use mathematical equations derived from observed data to predict future conditions. With the addition of computers, these mathematical equations can be linked together in increasingly sophisticated ways to model multiple factors in 3 dimensions. Even with advanced computing power, some factors within the model may be simplified. How they are represented within the model can lead to a degree of error in the outcome predicted by the model. Ultimately, the quality of a model is determined by its success in predicting events.

pageData.subTitle: Contour Maps
pageData.text: To determine potential flood risks, scientists, engineers, and insurance companies use a number of tools, including historic river flow, storm tide, and rainfall data; hydrological analysis; and topographic surveys. Topographic surveys can be represented graphically as maps with contour lines (see Figure 3). Each contour line represents an elevation on the terrain. Figure 3B shows the contour map from Figure 3A overlaid on the terrain it was mapped from. Elevations are marked on the map at set intervals, depending on the scale of the map. Smallscale maps might have a contour interval of 5 feet. Maps of a continent may have an interval of thousands of feet. All points connected by a given contour line are at the same elevation. Depressions in the landscape, such as craters and basins, are marked with a hatched line, as seen in Figure 4. In the following activities, you will be asked to use a contour map to generate a landform model. You will use this model to examine the consequences of <button class='glossary-text'>sea level rise</button>.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of activities 1 and 2 of this investigation. Before beginning, prepare the colored ice cubes. In activity 1, print the island contour map template. Then, cut the template to the lowest contour line. Next, roll out the clay into a thin sheet, cut the clay in the shape of the template, and place the clay shape into the plastic tray. Then, trim the map to the next contour line and repeat the process until your island has 4 layers.  In activity 2, prepare the salt water. Then, place the colored ice cube in the plastic tray and add the salt water, Next, estimate the initial water depth. Then, place coins on the island and estimate the depth of the water every 10 minutes until the ice has completely melted. Finally, observe if the coins are underwater before removing them and draining the water from the tray. Then continue to activity 3.

A map of the procedural workflow of activities 3-5 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, prepare the salt water. Then, place the colored ice cube on the clay island and add the salt water. Next, estimate the initial water depth. Then, place coins on the island and estimate the depth of the water every 30 minutes until the ice has completely melted. Next, observe if the coins are underwater before removing them and draining the water from the tray. In activity 4, prepare the salt water, add the pH indicator, and add the solution to the plastic tray. Then, measure the pH of the tray water. Next, place an Alka-Seltzer solution cup on the island. Then, observe color changes in the tray water at regular intervals for 60 minutes. Finally, observe the final color of the tray water. In activity 5, improve or expand on the model from activity 4.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following gases makes up the largest percentage of the atmosphere?
Which of the following statements about differential heating is true?

options.text: Darker materials heat faster than lighter colored materials.
Water has a low heat capacity relative to air.
Warmer fluids are denser than colder fluids.
Water vapor has a low heat capacity relative to other greenhouse gases.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the effect of carbon dioxide absorption by oceans?

options.text: The oceans’ pH decreases as carbon dioxide reacts with water to form carbonic acid.
The oceans’ biodiversity increases as phytoplankton use carbon dioxide for photosynthesis.
The oceans release oxygen as carbon dioxide displaces dissolved oxygen gas.
The oceans become cloudy as marine bacteria near the surface perform fermentation.
The oceans’ temperature increases as dissolved carbon dioxide absorbs infrared radiation.

assestmentData.question: Gases such as carbon dioxide and water vapor in the earth’s atmosphere insulate the planet because they absorb and re-emit what kind of radiation from the sun?
Which of these scenarios is an example of a positive feedback loop?

options.text: Warmer temperatures melt more of the arctic permafrost, releasing methane into the atmosphere, further raising temperatures.
An increase in CO<sub>2</sub> levels in the atmosphere leads to an increase in CO<sub>2</sub> in the oceans, stabilizing CO<sub>2</sub> levels.
Increased atmospheric temperatures and CO<sub>2</sub> promote plant and algal growth, increasing absorption of CO<sub>2</sub> from the atmosphere, lowering the CO<sub>2</sub> levels there.
Warmer air, carrying more moisture, produces more snow at high latitudes, leading to an increase in the albedo of the earth's surface and stabilizing temperatures.
Warmer, moister air produces more clouds, leading to an increase in the albedo of the earth's surface, stabilizing temperatures.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following does NOT play a role in sea level rise?

options.text: warmer temperatures causing water to expand at the equator
warmer temperatures causing water to expand at the poles

assestmentData.question: The following are safety considerations for this lab EXCEPT:

options.text: Bogen Universal Indicator can cause damage to organs if ingested.
Goggles, gloves and lab apron must be worn when handling Bogen Universal Indicator Solution and the Alka-Seltzer® effervescent tablets.
Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the activities.

assestmentData.question: Lottie lives in Iceland. Her friend Maricela, lives in Colombia. As they video chat, they discuss the weather: Lottie’s outdoor thermometer reads 20° C, while Maricela’s phone says her town is 31° C. Which of the following best accounts for this difference in temperature?

options.text: The equator receives direct sunlight while the poles receive more diffuse sunlight.
The equator is significantly closer to the sun than the poles.
The oceans at the equator are warmer than those at the poles.
Carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is concentrated at the equator.
Water vapor in the atmosphere is concentrated at the equator.

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.

typeBefore.text: At least 24 hours before Activities 2 and 3, prepare 2 colored ice cubes:

pageData.text: Fill each medicine cup with tap water to the 20-mL mark.
Add approximately 5 drops of food coloring to each cup.
Place the cups inside the plastic container to mitigate spills, and place the container in the freezer.
Allow the mixture to freeze for at least 24 hours.
Once the mixture is frozen, the cups may be removed from the plastic container.
In Activity 1, you will create a 3D landform out of clay using a contour map as a template. You will use this landform in Activities 2 and 3.

pages.title:
A
 Building a Model from a Contour Map (15 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Building a Model from a Contour Map (15 steps)

pageData.text: If you have not already, print the contour map template and cut out the island represented along the lowest contour line. This will eventually serve as the base of the island.
Take out a package of clay and knead the clay to soften it.
Using your hand, flatten the clay into a thin, round layer.

Place the flattened round on a piece of scrap paper or a plastic bag to prevent it from sticking to the work surface, and work or roll the clay into a thin 2- to 3-mm layer that is large enough to place the cutout on. (Try using the Sharpie<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> marker as a rolling pin.)
Place the island template on the clay and, using a pencil, trace around it, cutting into the clay.
Remove the template from the clay.

Peel the clay off the work surface and place the inner, template-shaped piece into the plastic container. Gently press down on any ridges formed on the layer by the cutting, making the layer as flat as possible.
Work the remaining clay into a ball.
Trim the outer contour off the template.
Repeat Steps 3 to 9 for the second and third contours, placing each subsequent contour on top of the previous one, building the island <button class='glossary-text'>model</button>.

Although the clay is nontoxic, care should be taken when working with it because the color will frequently transfer to your hands, clothes, and work surface. You may wish to wear gloves and an apron while working.

Roll out the fourth layer of clay. Place the template on the clay and cut the fourth contour in the clay. This time, however, do not place the cutout contour on top of the previous one, but leave it on your work space.
Trim the paper along the hatched line.
Place the ring paper template that you just cut out on the clay.
Trace the template with a pencil, cutting into the clay. This will form a ring from the fourth layer of clay.
Remove the thin ring of clay from your work paper and place it on the island model in the plastic container, completing your hill. You will use this container and landform in subsequent activities.

In Activity 2, you will use the landform created in Activity 1 to <button class='glossary-text'>model</button> how melting sea ice affects sea levels. This requires a colored ice cube prepared at least 24 hours before starting this activity (see Preparation section).

pages.title:
A
 Sea Ice and Sea Level Rise (11 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Sea Ice and Sea Level Rise (11 steps)

pageData.text: Fill the graduated cylinder with 150 mL of water, and then pour the water into the large plastic cup.
Add 1 tsp of salt and stir until the salt is completely dissolved to prepare saltwater.

Remove 1 colored ice cube from its cup (from the Preparation section), and place it in the container away from the island so that no part of the ice rests on the clay (See Figure 5). Leave the other colored ice cube in the freezer to use with Activity 3.
Pour the saltwater into the container, taking care not to pour water on the ice, until the bottom 2 layers of the island are completely covered. (You may not need all the saltwater prepared.)

Estimate the depth of the water in meters (m) represented in the based on the contours. Record that depth in Data Table 1: Sea Ice. Measure the actual depth with a ruler. Record that depth in centimeters (cm) in Data Table 1.
Place a coin on the north side of the island along the steepest slope, so that the edge of the coin barely touches the edge of the water.
Place the other coin on the south side of the island, also just touching the water, along a more gradual slope. These represent coastal cities with very different topography.

At 10-minute intervals, observe the model from above and from the side. You may see a layer of colored water developing. Estimate the depth of the water in meters, and measure the depth with the ruler in centimeters. Write your observations in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: When the ice has completely melted, record the depth of the water.
Record your observations of how much of each coin is underwater. Take a photograph of your completed model showing the locations of the coins relative to the water.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Remove the coins from the model. Without disturbing the island, gently pour the water out of the container into a sink. Flush the dyed water with running water for 30 seconds.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Diagram showing placement of ice and coins on the island model as well as placement of the white paper for helpful viewing.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram showing placement of ice and coins on the island model as well as placement of the white paper for helpful viewing.

pageData.text: Note: In order to view the water layers as they are forming, it may be helpful to view the water through the side of the container with a piece of white paper behind it.

In Activity 3, you will use the landform created in Activity 1 to <button class='glossary-text'>model</button> how melting glacial ice affects sea levels. This requires a colored ice cube prepared at least 24 hours before starting this activity (see Preparation section).

pages.title:
A
 Glacier Ice and Sea Level Rise (11 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Glacier Ice and Sea Level Rise (11 steps)

pageData.text: Fill the graduated cylinder with 150 mL of water, and pour it into the large plastic cup.
Add 1 tsp of salt and stir until the salt is completely dissolved to prepare saltwater.
Remove the remaining colored ice cube from its cup and place it on top of the island.
Pour the saltwater into the container, taking care not to pour water over the ice or the island, until the bottom 2 layers are completely covered. (You may not need all the saltwater prepared.)
Estimate the depth of the water based on the contours. Record that depth in Data Table 2: Glacier Ice. Measure the depth with a ruler. Record that depth in Data Table 2.
Place a coin on the north side of the island along the steepest slope, so that the coin edge barely touches the edge of the water.
Place the other coin on the south side of the island, also just touching the water, along a more gradual slope. These represent coastal cities with very different topography.

At 30-minute intervals, observe the from above and from the side. You may see a layer of colored water developing. Estimate the depth of the water in meters, and measure the depth with the ruler in centimeters. Write your observations in Data Table 2.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: When the ice has completely melted, estimate the depth of the water using the contours and measure the depth of the water with a ruler. Record your results in Data Table 2.
Record your observations of how much of each coin is underwater. Take a photograph of your completed model showing the location of the coins relative to the water.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Without disturbing the island, gently pour the water out of the container into a sink. Flush the dyed water with running water for 30 seconds.

In Activity 4, you will create an atmosphere with a high concentration of CO2 by submerging an effervescent tablet, such as an Alka-Seltzer® tablet, in water. In the presence of water, the components of effervescent antacid tablets—citric acid (C6H8O7) and sodium bicarbonate (baking soda, NaHCO3)—react to form sodium citrate (Na3C6H5O7), water, and carbon dioxide (CO2).
Rinse 1 medicine cup thoroughly before beginning this activity.
Fill the graduated cylinder with 150 mL of water, and pour the water into the large plastic cup.
Add 1 tsp of salt and stir until the salt is completely dissolved to prepare saltwater.
Add 20 drops (~1 mL) of Bogen Universal Indicator Solution to the saltwater. Gently swirl the cup to mix the solution into the water.
Pour this mixture into the container until the bottom 3 layers of the island <button class='glossary-text'>model</button> are covered. Take a photograph of your model showing the color of the water.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Using the Universal Indicator pH Color Chart, record the pH of the saltwater.
Add 10 mL water to the clean medicine cup.
Place the medicine cup on top of the landform.

Unwrap an Alka-Seltzer® tablet, and place it in the medicine cup. Quickly cover the container with the lid, ensuring that the container is closed and that the CO2 bubbling out of the medicine cup is contained.
Start the timer. Observe the surface layer of water from the side. At 1, 2, 5, and 10 minutes, record the color of the surface layer in Data Table 3.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Leave the model undisturbed for 1 hour. Observe the layers again, and record your observations. Take a photograph of your model showing the color of the water.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Activity 5, you will evaluate the <button class='glossary-text'>model</button> of <button class='glossary-text'>ocean acidification</button> in Activity 4 and improve upon it. You will design a new model to test ocean acidification by considering ways to make the model more realistic and control for additional factors.

typeBefore.text: Use the materials provided and the results of Activity 4 to improve or expand the <button class='glossary-text'>model</button>. For an additional option, 2 incense cones are included in the investigation materials. Incense cones, when lit, will release carbon dioxide into the closed container. Consider the following questions to help redesign your model:

pageData.text:
Were there any areas where the model differed from reality?
  1. Could you create a more realistic model?
  2. What factors would you change?

What factors might affect the outcome of the model experiment?
  1. Can you design an experiment to test the effects of one of those factors?
  2. How would you control factors not being tested?

text: Dispose of solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment, and return the materials to your equipment kit.
Dispose of the rinsed clay in a trash can.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

text: Describe the results of increasing atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> in the Activity 4 model.
How will the oceans be impacted by an increase in CO<sub>2</sub>?
Were Activities 2 and 3 effective models for demonstrating sea-level rise and the different effects of melting sea ice and glacier ice? What improvements would you make to the models?
Was Activity 4 an effective model for demonstrating ocean acidification due to increased CO<sub>2</sub>? What improvements would you make to the model?
How would the two cities, represented by coins in the models, be affected differently by sea level rise?

pageData.content: Figure 1. Sunlight hitting Earth at different latitudes
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Image of the sun’s light shining on Earth at an angle in a higher latitute, spreading the sunlight over more of Earth’s surface than the light shining at the equator.

pageData.content: Figure 2. Chemical reactions from dissolved CO<sub>2</sub> in seawater
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Dissolved carbon dioxide plus water can form carbonic acid, which can form bicarbonate and a hydrogen ion, which can form carbonate and two hydrogen ions. Each reaction can take place in reverse as well as forwards.
Figure 3A: Topographic maps with contour lines on one terrain.
Figure 3B: Contour map from Figure 2A overlaid on the terrain it was mapped from.
Figure 4: Diagram showing a hatched line as it would be used to mark a crater or basin

pageData.content: Figure 5. Activity 2 set up and viewing angle
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram showing placement of ice and coins on the island model as well as placement of the white paper for helpful viewing.

A map of the procedural workflow of activities 1 and 2 of this investigation. Before beginning, prepare the colored ice cubes. In activity 1, print the island contour map template. Then, cut the template to the lowest contour line. Next, roll out the clay into a thin sheet, cut the clay in the shape of the template, and place the clay shape into the plastic tray. Then, trim the map to the next contour line and repeat the process until your island has 4 layers.  In activity 2, prepare the salt water. Then, place the colored ice cube in the plastic tray and add the salt water, Next, estimate the initial water depth. Then, place coins on the island and estimate the depth of the water every 10 minutes until the ice has completely melted. Finally, observe if the coins are underwater before removing them and draining the water from the tray. Then continue to activity 3.

A map of the procedural workflow of activities 3-5 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, prepare the salt water. Then, place the colored ice cube on the clay island and add the salt water. Next, estimate the initial water depth. Then, place coins on the island and estimate the depth of the water every 30 minutes until the ice has completely melted. Next, observe if the coins are underwater before removing them and draining the water from the tray. In activity 4, prepare the salt water, add the pH indicator, and add the solution to the plastic tray. Then, measure the pH of the tray water. Next, place an Alka-Seltzer solution cup on the island. Then, observe color changes in the tray water at regular intervals for 60 minutes. Finally, observe the final color of the tray water. In activity 5, improve or expand on the model from activity 4.

data.title: Albedo
data.content: The amount of solar radiation reflected off the earth's surface and into outer space

data.title: Climate
data.content: The prevailing weather pattern over a long period of time

data.title: Condensable
data.content: Describes a type of greenhouse gas whose concentration in the atmosphere is dependent on temperature

data.title: Differential heating
data.content: The process by which different substances heat at different rates

data.title: Feedback
data.content: An event that takes place as a result of forcings

data.title: Feedback loop
data.content: A mechanism that either enhances or dampens the effect that triggers it

data.title: Forcing factor
data.content: A feature of the earth's climate change system that drives climate change; may be internal or external to the planet; also called a forcing

data.title: Greenhouse effect
data.content: The process of gases in the atmosphere trapping heat from solar radiation

data.title: Greenhouse gas
data.content: An atmospheric gas that absorbs infrared radiation

data.title: Heat capacity
data.content: A measure of how much heat it takes to raise the temperature of a substance by one degree

data.title: Model
data.content: A simplification of a complex process that isolates certain important factors

data.title: Negative feedback loop
data.content: A feedback loop where the product of a reaction leads to a decrease in that reaction

data.title: Ocean acidification
data.content: The process of decreasing levels of pH in the ocean, making it more acidic

data.title: Persistent
data.content: Describes a type of greenhouse gas that exists in the atmosphere much longer than condensable gases

data.title: Positive feedback loop
data.content: A feedback loop that exacerbates the effects of a small disturbance

data.title: Sea level rise
data.content: The increase in sea level elevation due to global climate change

data.title: Weather
data.content: The condition of the atmosphere in a given location at a specific time
